Posts.Content: Told I had breast cancer 5th December, biopsy results 18th, grade 3, IDC, Er Rich, waiting for HER2 (FISH), lumpectomy/nodal status tomorrow. I guess it feels like a road crash. Praying for small tumour and no nodal involvement. Good luck! Personally, hoping they will throw everything at me, and as quickly as possible given that it is Christmas and our local hospital in Wales is insanely busy.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed, chemo about to start

Posts.Content: It’s ridiculous how busy the hospitals are and feel sorry for staff. Hopefully HR2+ then!
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed, chemo about to start

Posts.Content: MollyRiver, thank you so much for sharing your plan to ask the oncologist questions based on different scenarios. My oncologist appointment is 4th January and all I have been able to focus on for the last 12 days is what will I do if my nodes aren’t clear!!!  I was told initially post mammogram and ultrasound that my lump was early and small, but at my pre op (for lumpectomy/ sentinel nodes) the nurse mentioned ‘in passing’ that it was IDC, Grade 3, E rich, Pr neg, HER2 positive (the latter has since changed to Her2 negative and the nurse said it was a pity because now I couldn’t have Herceptin). I am finding that the hardest part is waiting for more results and having anyone to talk to discuss my options. Your idea has helped me focus and scenario building is far more constructive than striding about like a headless chicken. Did I say thank you?!!!
Posts.Title: Can’t stop worrying

Posts.Content: Do you mind me asking how long the test results take to come back? I’m being given the test on Monday. Had my surgery 21st December and wondering if something in the way of treatment shouldn’t be started soon. Good luck with your results. Fingers crossed they will be low (or intermediate even) and you won’t need chemotherapy. Sue
Posts.Title: Can’t stop worrying

Posts.Content: Sorry to reply to an old post, but I Googled ‘did you know something was wrong before your breast cancer diagnosis?’ and this is where my search ended up! Well, for a year before my BC diagnosis I’d felt rubbish and had blood tests, seen a dietician, had a colonoscopy (found polyps), but nothing found to explain why I felt ancient, lethargic and no energy for life. The surgery nurse told me my nipple was leaning outwards, examined my breast, sent me for a mammogram. 5 weeks later had a WLE and sentinel node removal, found 3cm single receptor positive IDC (nodes clear). Am awaiting Onco Dx test results now before treatment decisions, but weirdly, I haven’t felt this well in a long time. Like my old self. Realise of course that I’m likely to feel a whole lot worse before I get better. But yes, I just knew something was wrong.
Posts.Title: Feeling old and tired before diagnosis.

Posts.Content: Anniekz, I was so active, and did my mountain leader course aged 50, but I just knew something was wrong after I hit 65. My asthma is well controlled thankfully. I’m waiting for chemo or radio and will find out Thursday. Good luck! Susan.
Posts.Title: Feeling old and tired before diagnosis.

Posts.Content: Mira, I also taught between university short term research/ lecturing contracts. I loved teaching and miss it so much. I understand how you must miss it.  Hitting 65 I would never have had the energy to travel to supply schools (taught out of county in none Welsh speaking schools). I gave up my short term research and lecturing in 2016 aged 65 as I was so lethargic. I also stopped working as an examiner due to brain fog. I also put on over a stone but ate next to nothing as I’m gluten and dairy intolerant. I had all sorts of tests, and in December 2016 a consultant in Cyprus said I had something quite serious wrong with my bloods (collapsed in the street for no reason except I was exhausted doing nothing). My GP ran tests last theough 2017 but found nothing. I just didn’t feel like me. In November 2017 our surgery nurse said my boobs didn’t look right and sent me for a mammogram. The rest is history. Thank heavens the tumour was found. In spite of surgery just one month ago, I’m packing ready to move home next week (mostly in-aided by my lovely but Neanderthal husband), but feel exactly like my old self. I find it all very strange.  I do hope you are doing well after your treatment and are able to enjoy the rest of your retirement. Susan.
Posts.Title: Feeling old and tired before diagnosis.

Posts.Content: Oh Mira, I just love Clearwater and the rest of the Gulf Coast. Hopefully I can go there in 2019 when I’ve been a year clear. I’m either starting chemo next week, or radiotherapy the week after. I’m just waiting for my Onco Dx test results to come back from California (I did offer to accompany my sample)!!  Everyone says I must be mad moving, but I left a home I loved 18 months ago to come to this home which has had bad karma as I didn’t want to leave my old home/ move to this one. My health problems began about the time I moved here. I think I mistook health problems for unhappiness. I’m now feeling so much better after the surgery and look forward to a fresh start. I just hope I don’t injure myself packing and carrying boxes (husband is Neanderthal and doesn’t take his eyes off the TV except to eat and sleep)!  Nice meeting you.  Susan.
Posts.Title: Feeling old and tired before diagnosis.
